executive_summary: Operators in the Ice Cream Stores industry serve dessert-craving customers a range of frozen treats, including ice cream, gelato and sorbet, as well as various toppings, ranging from crushed candies to flavored syrups. Despite increased per capita disposable income and per capita dairy consumption, ice cream stores have experienced a modest decline in demand over the past five years. With rising inflation pushing ice cream prices higher, consumers have opted for the ice cream gallons at the supermarkets, leaving the fresh-scooped cones or bowls offered at local ice cream shops. In addition, in 2020, industry revenue fell as consumers increased stock-up activity at supermarkets and visited industry establishments less due to the pandemic. Customers have gradually been returning to industry establishments considering growing vaccination rates, boosting industry

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Reduced Foot Traffic at Ice Cream Stores
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Ice cream shops that kept their establishments open took the necessary precautions, such as mandatory masks and gloves and pickup and delivery options. Still, consumers hesitated to visit industry establishments amid nationwide lockdown measures and turned to groceries or supermarkets to buy pints as stock-up activity has risen. Some consumers turned to comfort food amid the pandemic, which helped mitigate the industry's decline.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Ice Creams are Dessert Staples in the United States
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since individual consumers are the primary purchasers of ice creams, demand for ice cream, gelato and sorbet is primarily driven by income and spending trends. Over the past five years, per capita dairy consumption has increased, supporting industry growth. In addition, disposable income has also climbed over the past five years, resulting in climbing industry revenue. During summer, ice cream shops typically experience increased demand for frozen treats.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A Declining Healthy Eating Index has Supported Industry Revenue Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Both ice cream and gelato are milk-based products, typically jam-packed with sugar. Consumers have become less health-conscious, contributing to limited demand declines and industry revenue growth. Despite a decline in the healthy eating index, ice cream shops are experiencing increasing competition from shops that provide healthier alternatives to ice creams, with most of this competition stemming from frozen yogurt stores.

Ice cream shops have historically struggled with or avoided delivery, as maintaining small volumes of ice cream cold in an inconsistent environment without costly dry ice and polystyrene foam is an immense challenge. While ice cream shops struggled during the pandemic, take-out option expansions have given consumers the opportunity to bring ice cream back home with no delivery charge and less risk of melting.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE DECLINING HEALTHY EATING INDEX WILL SUPPORT INDUSTRY GROWTH OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: According to the Office of Disease Prevention and Health Promotion (DPHP), saturated fats, which are present in ice cream and gelato, increase consumers' blood cholesterol levels and the risk of developing coronary heart disease. The DPHP recommends keeping total saturated fat consumption low and limiting added sugar consumption to foods high in vitamins and minerals. However, demand for ice cream stores will climb as the healthy eating index declines, boosting industry revenue over the next five years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ICE CREAM STORES EXPERIENCE INTENSIFYING COMPETITION FROM EXTERNAL COMPETITORS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: According to the Department of Health, half a cup of ice cream has nearly twice as much saturated fat as the same amount of frozen yogurt. To compete with frozen yogurt shops and other dessert retailers, ice cream shops will offer healthier alternatives such as low-fat and vegan ice creams and sorbet, which have lower fat content.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE INDUSTRY PROFIT WILL INCH UPWARD AS MILK PRICES ARE EXPECTED TO LAG
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As demand for ice cream, sorbet and gelato rebounds, more stores will enter the industry. The price of milk is expected to decline over the next five years, reducing purchase costs for operators and resulting in climbing industry profit. For these shops to operate efficiently and keep up with demand, industry employment is also expected to increase.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: COMMUNITY PRESENCE AND CATERING WILL BECOME A CORNERSTONE OF ICE CREAM SCALES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Because cold ice cream transportation is awkward at best, ice cream catering services can take advantage by showing up at major community events, catering special get-togethers, and handing out samples on hot days. With a wheeled cooler and vehicle freezer bought for less than $10,000, ice cream shops can significantly expand their potential market radius. Ice cream is also accepted as one of the essential base desserts and is widely popular among all significant population segments, making ice cream shops ideal candidates for providing desserts to large crowds.

industry_definition: This industry comprises establishments that prepare or serve ice cream, ice cream treats, sorbet and gelato. Purchases may be consumed on-site, taken out or delivered. Ice cream is made from dairy products or dairy alternatives, such as soy milk. Gelato generally has a lower butterfat content than ice cream, while sorbet is a sweetened water that is flavored with fruit. Most stores offer ice cream, ice cream treats and ice cream with toppings.

There is no government assistance for ice cream stores. However, during COVID-19, ice cream stores received government assistance from the CARES Act.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Ice cream stores sell most ice cream over the counter
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This service model is common for ice cream stores and is similar to the style of fast-casual and fast-food restaurants. Counter-service ice cream stores are common because this model is versatile and can be located anywhere. Counter-service ice cream stores sell beverages, including milkshakes and soda floats.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Ice cream stores also sell packaged ice cream and other products for later consumption
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This segment also includes ice cream cakes and other desserts made in-store for some stores. This segment is particularly large among chains like Ben and Jerry's and Cold Stone Creamery because these companies also sell packaged ice cream to other retailers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Drive-through service has become an increasingly popular option for ice cream stores
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As a food that can be quickly prepared, ice cream is ideal for drive-through service because drive-through service is meant to be a fast model of food service. This model is popular with ice cream stores selling hot food. Dairy Queen is one of the most popular ice cream drive-throughs because the company applies the fast food model to ice cream.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Ice cream stores also rely on other delivery methods
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Aside from drive-through and counter service, ice cream stores also use different service models, including table service, car-side delivery and walk-up windows. Table service is often offered at larger ice cream stores and other food stores. Car-side delivery and walk-up windows are less common than counter stores because they have stricter location requirements.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Under the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 21 regulates ice cream and frozen desserts and establishes product quality standards.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: The act establishes labeling standards for the packaging of ice creams. Labels include standardized nutrition facts for the packaged ice cream. Nutritional labels provide information on serving sizes, calories and nutrients.
Ice cream stores are subject to regulations surrounding restaurant cleanliness and food preparation standards. The DOH also provides guidelines and regulations regarding health and safety standards.

barriers_points.barrier_description: This industry is labor-intensive by nature, as store staff is required to undertake a series of tasks.

basis_points.basis_description: Price-based competition has intensified following a growing desire for low-priced, private-label supermarket brands, particularly for bulk ice cream products.

basis_points.basis_title: Premium ice cream less sensitive to price
basis_points.basis_description: The desire for premium ice cream is less sensitive to price changes since these products target a more affluent consumer group.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The largest ice cream companies are all franchise ice cream brands, including Baskin-Robbins, Cold Stone Creamery, Dairy Queen and Ben & Jerry's.
Stores that offer specialty options like unique flavors, house-made ice cream, and local ingredients have grown in popularity over the past five years.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase costs have increased during the period along with the price of milk
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs are expected to account for 43.7% of revenue in 2023, up from 43.0% in 2018. Shop owners must keep their shops fully stocked to serve their customers. Shops that make their own ice cream must purchase all the component ingredients required to make those products, while those that sell already-made goods must purchase the products themselves. Other purchase costs include products made to hold these desserts, such as cones and bowls, utensils, storage products, toppings and other items.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Trends in Consumer Spending and Consumption Primarily Determine Demand for Ice Cream
volatility_points.volatility_description: As income and dairy consumption have both increased over the past five years, industry revenue has climbed. However, in 2020, industry revenue lagged due to economic slowdowns and the countrywide lockdown during the pandemic. Ice cream stores may experience increased sales during summer, as frozen treats are typically more popular during warmer months.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Health Concerns Continue to Pose a Threat to the Industry
volatility_points.volatility_description: Two of the industry's main products, ice cream and gelato, are often considered unhealthy, as they are typically high in fat and sugar. While sorbet products are made with water instead of milk and are sometimes mixed with fruit, they also can be high in sugar, deterring health-conscious consumers.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: By offering a variety of products, operators can appeal to a wide range of consumers.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Consumers are more likely to spend on industry products, which are typically more expensive than similar products offered at grocery stores, when per capita disposable income is high.

FAQs.question: Have rising input costs negatively affected your company's sales?
FAQs.answer: Milk is one of the largest purchase costs for industry operators. When the price of milk rises, operators may raise their prices to counteract increasing purchase costs.

FAQs.question: Does your company lease equipment to reduce overhead costs?
Industry machinery, such as batch freezers, are typically very costly, running upwards of $30,000.
FAQs.answer: This is a statement, not a question.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Most industry operations must be performed by employees. To more effectively reduce wage costs, employers typically employ part-time workers.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: Keeping track of popular products and ensuring they are in stock is crucial to maintaining a loyal consumer base.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Ice cream stores are subject to Department of Health regulations surrounding restaurant cleanliness and food preparation standards.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The National Ice Cream Retailers Association advocates for ice cream retailers and provides resources and support to ice cream businesses across the country.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: The industry's largest operators typically experience higher profit margins than the industry average.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Ice cream production equipment, including batch freezers, mixers and industrial-grade machinery, can be costly to purchase but are necessary for industry operators.

FAQs.question: Do you make your own ice cream and other products, or do you order your products from a supplier? Would you consider making your own to save money?
FAQs.answer: Keeping input costs low is crucial for industry operators that want to yield higher profit margins.

FAQs.question: If you don't already have one, would your establishment benefit from a drive-up or walk-up window?
FAQs.answer: Certain models of service, such as walk-up windows and drive-through windows, require specific types of property.

FAQs.question: If you do not make your own ice cream, do you keep efficient records of how often you need a delivery and how long your ice cream remains fresh?
FAQs.answer: Ice cream does not have a long shelf life, and ice cream kept in a freezer for too long gets freezer burnt, so having steady supply is important to maintain quality control.

FAQs.question: Do you offer special deals to entice customers to come into your store, like buy-one-get-one deals or punch cards for repeat visits?
FAQs.answer: When consumers have more disposable income in their pockets, they are more likely to spend on discretionary items, such as ice cream, gelato and sorbet sold by ice cream stores, rather than purchasing these products prepackaged at a supermarket or not at all.

FAQs.question: As more consumers develop lactose allergies, how have you adapted your product offerings? Can you carve out a niche, local offering?
FAQs.answer: Per capita dairy consumption measures the total amount of milk products consumed in the United States. Health concerns, including milk allergies and lactose intolerance, have a negative effect on total dairy consumption.

FAQs.question: Have you considered adapting your products to cater to a more health-conscious consumer? How can you combat a potential decline in consumption?
FAQs.answer: Most ice cream, gelato and sorbet treats are made with some sort of sugar or sweetener product. As a result, when per capita sugar and sweetener consumption increases, demand for industry products also rises.
